statement: The government can arrest anyone without giving a reason.
explanation: Article 22 protects against arbitrary arrest. Every arrested person must be informed of the grounds of arrest and produced before a magistrate within 24 hours.

statement: Every citizen has the right to vote after turning 18.
explanation: Article 326 establishes universal adult suffrage. Every citizen of India who is 18 years or older has the right to vote in elections.

statement: Private companies can deny jobs based on a person's caste.
explanation: While Article 15 directly applies to the State, the spirit of equality extends through various laws. Caste-based discrimination is prohibited under the Constitution and related laws.

statement: Citizens can peacefully assemble without weapons.
explanation: Article 19(1)(b) guarantees all citizens the right to assemble peaceably and without arms. This enables peaceful protests and gatherings.

statement: The President can declare emergency and suspend all fundamental rights permanently.
explanation: While emergency provisions exist, Article 20 and 21 (right to life and personal liberty) cannot be suspended even during emergencies after the 44th Amendment.

statement: Children between 6-14 years have a fundamental right to free education.
explanation: Article 21A, added by the 86th Amendment in 2002, makes free and compulsory education a fundamental right for all children aged 6-14 years.

statement: A state can make laws favoring one religion over another.
explanation: India is a secular state. Articles 25-28 guarantee freedom of religion and prohibit religious discrimination by the State.

statement: Every person has the right to move freely throughout India.
explanation: Article 19(1)(d) grants all citizens the right to move freely throughout the territory of India, subject only to reasonable restrictions.

statement: Forced labor, even if paid below minimum wage, is allowed.
explanation: Article 23 prohibits traffic in human beings, begar (forced labor), and other similar forms of forced labor. Any violation is punishable by law.

statement: Citizens have the right to practice any profession or carry on any trade.
explanation: Article 19(1)(g) guarantees citizens the freedom to practice any profession, or carry on any occupation, trade, or business.

statement: The government can impose censorship on all forms of media without any limits.
explanation: While reasonable restrictions exist under Article 19(2), blanket censorship violates freedom of speech and expression guaranteed under Article 19(1)(a).

statement: Every citizen can approach the Supreme Court directly if fundamental rights are violated.
explanation: Article 32 gives citizens the right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of fundamental rights. Dr. Ambedkar called it the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution.

statement: Untouchability in any form is punishable by law.
explanation: Article 17 abolishes untouchability and forbids its practice in any form. The Protection of Civil Rights Act, 1955 makes it a punishable offense.

statement: Only men can inherit ancestral property under constitutional law.
explanation: The Constitution guarantees equality before law (Article 14) and prohibits discrimination based on sex (Article 15). Personal laws have been amended to ensure equal inheritance rights.

statement: Minorities have the right to establish their own educational institutions.
explanation: Article 30 grants minorities (religious and linguistic) the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.
